results.title: A Turning point
results.creator_credit: Noel Williamson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Noel Williamson joined the RAAF because he wanted adventure and he wanted to serve. While his limited education kept him grounded, he speaks fondly of his time in the RAAF, and the opportunities that he grasped with both hands once the war ended.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Noel Williamson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Noel Williamson joined the RAAF because he wanted adventure and he wanted to serve. While his limited education kept him grounded, he speaks fondly of his time in the RAAF, and the opportunities that he grasped with both hands once the war ended.

results.title: The Sleeping dragon
results.creator_credit: Graham Atkinson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: The attack on the World Trade Centre in September 2001 resonated with veterans like Graham Atkinson, reminding him of his time in Vietnam during the 1960s and 1970s. Graham tells of how being in the army taught him strength, respect and a sense of dignity for all. Vietnam was a turning point for this Indigenous Australian. He returned highly politicised and railed against violence in his community but left with decades of unresolved memories.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Graham Atkinson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Compression
results.brief_description: Ricky Morris is the 21st member of his family to see active service for Australia. He is proud to be part of the fighting Gunditjmarra people. His story looks at the invisible pressures modern soldiers constantly face and his realisation that this was shared by his family waiting for him at home.

results.title: Back to being black
results.brief_description: John Lovett reflects on the injustices experienced by his father and so many other indigenous war veterans who were not recognised or afforded the same benefits as their white mates when they returned from service.
results.description: John Lovett reflects on the injustices experienced by his father and so many other indigenous war veterans who were not recognised or afforded the same benefits as their white mates when they returned from service.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Worlds → MW-04. Costume Design → MW-04-C06

results.title: FAWN
results.credit_line: Commissioned by ACMI as part of a larger project commissioned by RISING
results.brief_description:
FAWN connects characters from popular culture with everyday people who have the lived experience of losing a parent. Dressed in a kind of orphan drag and performing acts of care on each other, they form temporary bonds and act out unlikely intimacies. FAWN queers the notion of family and acknowledges that loss doesn’t always lead to a heroic coming of age adventure.

This work was commissioned by ACMI as part of a larger project commissioned by RISING.

results.title: More Than Just a Game
results.material_description: Videogame, arcade machine handcrafted from reclaimed Australian blackwood, LED lettering, custom flooring
results.brief_description:
“Just like in the arcade games of the past, the government initiatives that exist are currently about us, without us. I want us to be seen, to have a say that enables us to take back control.”

Jarra Karalinar Steel conjures the nostalgic excitement of 1990s videogame arcades in More Than Just a Game. At its centre is The Adventures of Dolly, a playable game made with Wiradjuri and Ngiyampaa illustrator Charlotte Allingham. Take the controls and take Dolly on a journey through an alternate reality or not-so-distant future of Melbourne’s CBD, featuring iconic trams and Swanston Street.Growing up, videogame protagonists weren’t relatable to Jarra.

This work remedies that, giving First Peoples a chance to see ourselves imagined in a videogame – made for us, by us. Through The Adventures of Dolly, custom possum and wallaby spirit flooring and the hand-carved arcade cabinet, Jarra reclaims a place that hasn’t reflected our experiences. She brings Indigenous stories into gaming, inspiring the next generation and giving us power to determine our own futures.

constellations_primary.name: Indigenous futurisms
constellations_primary.description: An exploration of works that put First Peoples futurisms first.

constellations_other.name: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls
constellations_other.description: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls explores the reality of living in Mparntwe (Alice Springs) through the eyes of the artists, who grew up there. Place and Indigenous representation are also vital to the other works in this Constellation.

Game designed in collaboration with Charlotte Allingham

Game programmed by Peter Russell Adams

Arcade cabinet made with assistance from David Brophy
